description: Number of non-unitary prime divisors of n!.
comments: A non-unitary prime divisor for n! cannot exceed n/2. a(n)=PrimePi[n/2]
formula: A prime divisor of x is non-unitary iff its exponent is at least 2 in the prime power factorization of x. In general, GCD[p, x/p]=1 or p. Cases are counted when GCD[p, n/p]>1.
example: 10!=2*2*2*2*2*2*2*2*3*3*3*3*5*5*7. The non-unitary prime divisors are 2, 3, and 5 because their exponents exceed 1, so a(10)=3.  The only unitary prime divisor of 10! is 7.
maple: with(numtheory); A056172:=n->pi(floor(n/2)); seq(A056172(k),k=1..100); # _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Sep 30 2013
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jul 27 2000
extensions: Example corrected by _Jon E. Schoenfield_, Sep 30 2013
